video: Watch Malala Yousafzai's Nobel Peace Prize acceptance speech.mp4

scenes.audio_speech: I'm proud, well in fact I'm very proud, to be the first Pashtun, the first Pakistani and the youngest person to receive this award.
Thank you.

objects.label: person
objects.movement: mostly stationary, moving in a loop

objects.label: person

scenes.audio_speech: You
Thank you.

Along with that, I'm pretty certain that I'm also the first recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize who still fights with her younger brothers. I want there to be peace everywhere, but my brothers and I are still working on that.
I'm I'm also

scenes.audio_speech: We are also honored to receive this award together.
with Kailash Satyarthi, who has been a chamber
for children's rights for a long time. Twice as long, in fact, than I have been alive.
I am proud that we can work together.

objects.label: person
objects.movement: moving up-left, moving in a loop

scenes.audio_speech: We can work together and show the world that an Indian and a Pakistani can work together and achieve their goals of children's rights.

objects.label: chair
objects.movement: mostly stationary, moving in a loop

scenes.audio_speech: Thank you. Thank you.
Thank you.
You

Dear brothers and sisters, I was named after the inspirational Malalai of Mewand, who is the Pashtun Joan of Arc. The word Malala means grief-stricken, sad, but in order to lend some happiness to it, my grandfather would always call me Malala, the happiest girl in the world. And today, I am very happy that we are together fighting for an important cause.

objects.label: person
objects.movement: moving left, moving in a loop

scenes.audio_speech: This award is not just for me, it is for all of you.

objects.label: person
objects.movement: mostly stationary, moving in a loop

scenes.audio_speech: just for me. It is for those forgotten children who want education. It is for those frightened children who want peace. It is for those voiceless children who want change. I'm here to stand up for their rights, to raise their voice. It is not time to pity them. It is not time to pity them. It is time to take action. So it becomes the last time, the last time. So it becomes the last time that we see a child deprived of education.

objects.label: person
objects.movement: moving right, getting farther, moving in a loop

scenes.audio_speech: Thank you.
You
You
You

I have found that people describe me in many different ways. Some people call me the girl who was shot by the Taliban. And some, the girl who fought for her rights. Some people call me a Nobel laureate now. However, my brothers still call me that annoying bossy sister. As far as I know, I'm just a committed and even stubborn person who wants to see every child getting quality education, who wants to see women having equal rights, and who wants peace in every corner of the world.
